title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and efficiency. Eligible projects aim to mitigate traffic congestion, reduce emissions, save energy, and enhance railroad operations. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving railroad-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and repairing track structures. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or constructing maintenance or passenger facilities. Eligible projects must be included in state plans. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" must be included in state plans and require a 20% cost sharing from non-Federal sources. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to states based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. Additional discretionary amounts are at the Secretary's discretion. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 20% of grant funds for projects of national significance with the greatest public benefit. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS: The Secretary of Transportation must ensure that workers on projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES: At least 10% of funds under this Act must go to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. The term "rail miles" refers to route miles, not track miles, and "railroad" includes freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation. SEC. 201. EXCISE TAX ON SALE OF CERTAIN TRAIN EQUIPMENT. A new subchapter is added to the Internal Revenue Code for imposing taxes on railroad locomotives and rolling stock. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. Owners can install parts or accessories within 6 months of the equipment being placed in service. A 5% tax is imposed on specified railroad equipment parts or accessories installed within 6 months of being placed in service. Owners are secondarily liable for the tax if installed by their business. The amendments for railroad locomotives and rolling stock will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code, including sections on transportation of persons, transportation of property, and definitions and special rules. The Internal Revenue Code imposes a tax on taxable rail transportation of persons and property. The tax rates are 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases. The tax is paid by the person making the payment. The tax imposed on taxable rail transportation of property is 1 percent of the amount paid for such transportation. The tax is paid by the person making the payment, except for payments made outside the United States, where the tax is paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States. The tax on taxable rail transportation of property in the United States is 1 percent of the amount paid for the transportation. The tax is paid by the person furnishing the last segment of the taxable transportation. SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. The term "transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders, with the initial transporter collecting the tax. Refunds on untaxed tickets require tax deduction. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" in the US requires payment of the tax imposed by section 4241. Refunds on untaxed tickets involve deducting any tax due and reporting uncollected amounts to the Secretary. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier must pay it under regulations prescribed by the Secretary. The Code is amended to insert a new item before the subchapter B section. The amendments made by this section regarding transportation by rail will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new section, SEC. 9511, is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, establishing the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes related to trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes related to trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund are available for expenditures to carry out title I of the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by various sources and available for expenditures to carry out the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
